title-group.article-title: Alterations in diaphragmatic activity preceding and during intermittent hypoxaemia events in preterm infants

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To assess the activity of the diaphragm using electromyography (dEMG) prior and during apnoea-induced intermittent hypoxaemia (IH) events in preterm infants

sec.title: Design
sec.p: A single-centre observational study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Neonatal intensive care unit.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Preterm infants (<32 weeks of gestation) experiencing IH events with a frequency of >1/hour

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Heart rate, oxygen saturation (SpO2) and dEMG were measured for 24 hours. dEMG data were processed for all IH events resulting in a SpO2<80%. Events were scored by two reviewers as central, obstructive or mixed. Subsequently, minimum (dEMGmin) and maximum (dEMGmax) diaphragmatic activity were calculated in three time periods (5–1 min prior, 1 min prior and during the desaturation) for each event. The dEMG activity over time was also compared between the different apnoea types.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: 20 infants (gestational age 27.6±1.3 weeks) were included. A total of 591 IH events were used for analysis of which 88 (14.9%), 239 (40.4%) and 264 (44.7%) were scored as central, obstructive and mixed, respectively. In the 1 min before the actual IH, dEMGmax and dEMGmin dropped for central and increased for obstructive events. Central and obstructive events also differed during the actual event (dEMGmin 6.1 vs 8.4 µV and dEMGmax 9.4 vs 13.3 µV, both p<0.001 for central vs obstructive events). Mixed events did not show a distinct dEMG pattern.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: dEMG can detect and characterise central and obstructive apnoea before the IH event occurs, which supports development of automated detection and classification of apnoea events.

caption.title: WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN ON THIS TOPIC

list-item.p: Diaphragm activity changes significantly in the minute leading up to the IH event.
Measurement of diaphragm activity is useful in distinguishing different types of hypoxaemic events.

sec.title: HOW THIS STUDY MIGHT AFFECT RESEARCH, PRACTICE OR POLICY

list-item.p: The results of this study should be used to develop an online, continuous monitoring algorithm able to detect and classify the origin of the IH events.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intermittent hypoxaemia (IH) events are common in preterm infants and often accompanied by bradycardia. One of the main causes of IH events in preterm infants is apnoea of prematurity (AOP).1 2 These apnoeas can be central (no neural drive to breathe), obstructive (upper airway obstruction) or mixed (features of central and obstructive present) in nature.3 Although short apnoeic periods and periodic breathing itself have not been shown to be harmful, increasing evidence is emerging that IH lasting >1 min are associated with long-term morbidities.4 5

Therefore, prevention of apnoea resulting in prolonged hypoxaemia is critical. To enable prevention and timely intervention, adequate continuous monitoring of the infants’ cardiorespiratory status is necessary. In addition to oxygen saturation (SpO2) and heart rate, monitoring spontaneous breathing effort is key to detecting apnoea. Chest impedance (CI) and/or flow measurement(s) are the most widely used techniques for breaths detection, but these techniques can be inaccurate in infants on non-invasive respiratory support. Both non-breathing-related thoracic movements in awake and active infants, as well as air leakages at the patient interface, make it difficult to accurately assess respiration, and thus, detect apnoea.

Transcutaneous diaphragmatic electromyography (dEMG) is a promising technique to overcome these limitations. dEMG measures the electrical activity of the diaphragm, the primary muscle responsible for breathing in (preterm) infants. The diaphragmatic activity provides insight into the infant’s breathing pattern and the measured signal is suitable for detecting AOP.6 7 Furthermore, dEMG can also quantify the breathing effort.8 9 Recently, it has been shown that dEMG can also be measured with standard ECG/CI electrodes, by repositioning the electrodes to the costal-abdominal margin.10 This makes it possible to continuously assess diaphragm activity, without the need for additional skin electrodes on the infant’s chest or special dEMG equipment. Even though previous research has shown that the dEMG signal can be used to distinguish between the different types of apnoea events, the dEMG signal has not yet been used to describe the activity pattern of the diaphragm prior to and during an IH event.7

Therefore, this study aims to describe the activity of the diaphragm before and during IH events in preterm infants. We hypothesise that the diaphragm’s activity changes markedly prior to an IH event and that different types of apnoea will show different diaphragm activity patterns.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This single-centre, prospective, observational study was performed in the level III neonatal intensive care unit of the Emma Children’s Hospital, Amsterdam UMC, Amsterdam, The Netherlands. Patients were included between May 2023 and February 2024. Patients or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this study.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Enrolment criteria were: a postmenstrual age between 26 and 34 weeks, on non-invasive respiratory support, standard cardiorespiratory monitoring using ECG/CI and IH events >1/hour, with or without tactile stimulation. Infants with (congenital) defects that restricted electrode placement were excluded from study participation.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients were included in the study after obtaining parental informed consent. The patients could not be involved in the design, recruitment, conduction and dissemination of results of this study. Neither could we ask the participants about the burden of the study.

sec.title: Study protocol
sec.p: To perform the dEMG measurement, the standard ECG electrodes (RedDot, 3M, USA) were repositioned to the diaphragm area for a 24-hour measurement, two active electrodes bilateral at the costal margin in the midclavicular line and one reference on the sternum, as described previously.6 During the measurement, standard ECG monitoring was continued by choosing the ECG lead with an acceptable signal-to-noise ratio. SpO2 was measured peripherally using photoplethysmography. All signals were presented on the patient monitor (Intellivue MX750; Philips Healthcare, Eindhoven, the Netherlands) and stored in a secured cloud-based database (Snowflake, Montana, USA) at a sample rate of 500 Hz. dEMG signal analysis was performed offline after data extraction.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The respiratory breathing waveform was derived from the dEMG measurements, by filtering baseline noise and removing cardiac interface with the gating technique, as described previously.10 11 Using the recorded SpO2 data, all desaturations below 80% were defined as potential IH events and subjected to a detailed assessment of the SpO2, HR and dEMG activity, prior to and during the event.

Segments of dEMG data from 5 min prior to the end of the selected IH event were extracted. Event plots were then created, showing SpO2 (which defined IH) and dEMG activity. Subsequently, two assessors (GJH and RWvL) independently assessed the dEMG and SpO2 data prior to and during the IH event and classified the events as central, obstructive, mixed AOP or noise. An event was scored as central if diaphragmatic activity decreased (a drop of at least 50% activity) and no breathing activity could be identified. Obstructive was defined as an increased inspiratory diaphragmatic activity compared with baseline (increase of at least 50%), although the patient still (subsequently) desaturated, suggesting effort against an obstructed upper airway (see figure 1). In cases where a short period (5–10 s) of no dEMG activity (ie,central features) was followed by a period of increased activity (ie, obstructive features), or vice versa, this event was scored as a mixed event. An event was scored as noise when either the dEMG or SpO2 signal was deemed uninterpretable. Disagreement in classification was resolved by asking the opinion of a third assessor (LA). If there were multiple scored desaturations below 80% within 1 min or if the SpO2 between multiple desaturations did not increase above 90%, these separate periods were scored as a single IH event.

caption.title: Representative plots of IH events used for scoring the event as central (A) or obstructive (B). Top trace, diaphragm activity (dEMG), bottom trace, oxygen saturation. It can be seen that prior to the drop in saturation, dEMG activity changes. dEMG, diaphragm using electromyography; IH, intermittent hypoxaemia; SpO2, oxygen saturation, HF, heart frequency.

sec.title: dEMG analysis
sec.p: Diaphragm activity prior and during the IH events was determined second-by-second, instead of breath-by-breath, because the entire period was of interest and no breaths could be detected during the apnoea itself. As a proxy for the base and average maximum inspiratory activity of the diaphragm, the minimum (dEMGmin) and maximum (dEMGmax) diaphragm activity values were determined each second.

To assess diaphragm activity over time, the dEMG data were divided into three windows: from 5 to 1 min prior to the hypoxaemia event, 1 min prior till the start of the hypoxaemia event and during the actual hypoxaemia event (with variable length, dependent on the duration of the desaturation). When multiple events were merged, the first drop in saturation was defined as the start of the event. Lastly, the continuous (1 s) data were used as well to visually assess and describe the trends in diaphragm activity, HR and SpO2 prior to and during the IH event. To investigate the overall behaviour, all these single-event traces were averaged to describe the overall diaphragmatic activity during a central, obstructive or mixed apnoea event.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: No formal sample size could be calculated in this study. Therefore, we aimed for a convenience sample of 20 infants. The average activity for each of the three different time windows was calculated, followed by comparative analysis between the different time windows. The diaphragmatic activity was also compared between the different types of apnoea. Analysis of variance or Kruskal-Wallis testing was used with post hoc testing when appropriate. The statistical analyses were performed in SPSS (V.28; IBM). A p<0.05 was defined as statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: 20 infants were included in this study, with a mean postmenstrual age of 29.2±1.7 weeks (table 1). Patients received caffeine as standard care during all measurements. 1490 events with desaturations below 80% were identified, of which 196 (13.1%) were discarded as noise. Scoring of the events resulted in 106 (8.2%) central, 507 (39.2%) obstructive and 681 (52.6%) mixed events. After merging of the events that occurred within 1 min of each other, 591 events remained. 88 (14.9%) were defined as central, 239 (40.4%) as obstructive and 264 (44.7%) as mixed events.

tr.td: Respiratory support at the start of the measurement

fn.p: FiO2, fractional inspired oxygen; nCPAP, nasal continuous positive airway pressure; nIPPV, nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation; PEEP, positive end-expiratory pressure; PIP, peak inflation pressure.

sec.p: The dEMG analysis showed there were clear changes in diaphragm activity over time, and also distinct patterns between different types of apnoea (figure 2). In central events, dEMGmin and dEMGmax were already significantly lower during the last minute prior to the event compared with the period 5–1 min before the event (dEMGmax 7.5 µV vs 10.9 µV and dEMGmin 5.5 µV vs 7.2 µV, respectively, p<0.01), and remained low during the event. Obstructive events showed an opposite behaviour with diaphragmatic activity increasing during the last minute before the event compared with the period 5–1 min before the event (dEMGmax 14.6 µV vs 11.4 µV and dEMGmin 9.5 µV vs 8.2 µV, respectively, p<0.01). The statistical analysis of the mixed events group did not show clear differences in diaphragmatic activity between the three time windows, but the variation in activity in these mixed events over time was large.

caption.title: Overview of maximum (A) and minimum diaphragm activity (B) in the time frames leading up to desaturation event, with significant differences over time (indicated with the horizontal black lines) and between central and obstructive events (horizontal grey lines). The boxes show that the difference between obstructive and central events is present 1 min prior and during the event. dMEG, diaphragm using electromyography.

sec.p: Comparing the diaphragmatic activity of the different types of events within each time window showed no differences between events in the period 5–1 min before the onset. However, during the last minute before and during the event, both dEMGmax and dEMGmin were significantly lower in the central apnoea compared with the obstructive apnoea (figure 2).

When inspecting the time trends in diaphragm activity, SpO2 and HR, it becomes clear that in central events, on average, a more gradual desaturation (from average 95% to 75% in 30 s) and a longer recovery (up to 30 s) is seen compared with events classified as obstructive, which showed on average a drop in saturation within seconds (from average 92% to 79% in 5 s, see figure 3). Moreover, changes in dEMGmax and dEMGmin were observed longer before desaturation in central apnoea events than in obstructive events, that is, breathing effort changed earlier. Lastly, in the mixed events, there were no apparent changes in dEMG parameters over time when analysing summarised dEMG data.

caption.title: Average trajectory of diaphragm activity (bottom two lines) and the heart rate (HR) and oxygen saturation (SpO2) (top two lines), for all central, obstructive and mixed events. The three categories show distinctive patterns of diaphragm activity (drop in central, increase in obstructive and averaged to a stable level during mixed events). The change in dEMG activity in the first two categories is followed by a change in SpO2, whereas in the mixed events, non-clear dEMG change is seen. dEMG, diaphragm using electromyography.

sec.p: With respect to the vital signs, the change in HR was different between the types of events. A large HR decrease was seen in central events (on average 160 bpm prior to the event with a drop on average to 120 during the IH event), while the HR remained in a physiological range in obstructive events (±160 bpm), although the variation in HR increased during this event. Mixed events showed a more prominent drop in SpO2 compared with HR.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the first study that assessed changes in diaphragmatic activity before and during IH events in preterm infants. The results show that changes in diaphragmatic activity differ between different types of apnoea events. Central apnoea events can be characterised by a decline in dEMG activity before desaturation, while obstructive apnoea events show an increase in dEMG activity, prior to desaturation. Notably, mixed events did not show a clear dEMG pattern.

Similar to previous studies, the most frequently occurring events in our cohort of preterm infants were obstructive and mixed apnoea.3 12 13 However, it is important to note that these studies used different techniques to measure spontaneous breathing, such as changes in flow at the airway opening or CI. Both these techniques have important flaws as they can be hampered by air leakage or breathing-unrelated chest movements, which may compromise their accuracy in classifying apnoea.7 14 15 In this study, events were scored using dEMG, a relatively new approach as it directly measures the activity of the main respiratory muscle. This difference in measurement technique could also explain the differences in distribution between the three types of apnoea. Where previous studies showed less obstructive apnoea, most likely dEMG can detect more obstructive apnoea, with a reduction in central/mixed events.13 16

The current study adds knowledge on the performance and use of dEMG as a monitoring tool, as we performed long-term dEMG measurements, during which changes in body position, nursing interventions and kangaroo care were present, that to date have not been described yet. Furthermore, we used standard ECG equipment with repositioned electrodes, facilitating continuous dEMG assessment in clinical practice.10 Although longer measurements naturally come with more signal artefacts, we demonstrate that it is feasible to investigate the occurrence of IH events with an acceptable percentage of noisy data.

The clinical relevance of monitoring IH events is evident, and besides introducing a novel technique, our study also shows the ability to gain better insight into the origin of an IH event using dEMG. Our results are complementary to the study of Gaertner et al, who used a different monitoring technique to assess lung volume changes during IH events.17 While our results show a gradual decrease in diaphragm activity in central events, they observed that lung volume decreases during IH events and recovers in the first five breaths after the apnoea. This gradual decrease was also seen in SpO2 during central events, which suggests that when breathing stops, the available oxygen is consumed and the saturation drops gradually. On the other hand, during obstructive events, the saturation dropped more suddenly, possibly due to the higher metabolic demand as a result of the increased effort to reopen the airways. Combining these findings suggests that the fall in diaphragm activity leads to a drop in lung volume, resulting in an oxygen desaturation, that is, an IH event. Together, these results provide a comprehensive image of the physiology and highlight the importance of optimal monitoring of the respiratory status of preterm infants, preferably multimodular.

The aetiology of bradycardia accompanying an apnoea event remains uncertain, but it is hypothesised that the decrease in HR is secondary to hypoxaemia or induced by inhibitory reflexes via laryngeal afferents.2 18 If the HR response is considered secondary, the expected sequence is a decline in SpO2, followed by alterations in HR. However, our findings challenge this assumption, as HR sometimes tends to drop prior to desaturation during central events. Several factors might play a role in this finding, including the averaging time of the saturation sensor or the physiological inhibitory reflexes during the event. The relationship between apnoea, bradycardia and the role of laryngeal receptors needs further investigation, as their interaction is not yet fully understood in preterm infants.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: When interpreting the results, it is important to note that no formal definition exists on when a dEMG signal is defined as being apnoeic. An additional breathing reference signal is ideally required to formally define apnoea detected by dEMG. However, as previous studies have shown (1) good agreement between dEMG and respiratory rate6 and (2) studies measuring diaphragm activity through the transoesophageal route use similar classifications,19 no extra reference signal was recorded in this study. Nevertheless, it should be noted that the fact the scoring was done solely based on dEMG could have introduced a risk of bias with respect to the outcome measures on dEMG signal strength.

Another limitation is the fact that during the 24-hour measurements, no annotations were made regarding clinical events (eg, whether the nurse had to stimulate the patient), which could have influenced the interpretation of signal artefacts. Lastly, in a future study, it could be very interesting to split mixed events into two categories: those starting with an obstructive component and those that initiate with a central component. In that way, the physiology of these events can be better understood. Now, we hypothesise that, based on the current results, obstructive and central components levelled each other out, resulting in an overall stable dEMG pattern.

sec.title: Clinical implications
sec.p: Although the reduction and increase in diaphragmatic activity during, respectively, central and obstructive apnoea is not a new finding, the fact that these changes already start 30 s up to 2 min prior to the actual desaturation is very intriguing and has not been described before. It provides an interesting window for clinical intervention to prevent severe and prolonged IH. The data collected in this study support future steps to develop an online software algorithm capable of early detection of apnoea events from the dEMG signal and classifying them as central, obstructive or mixed. Adding saturation and heart rate signal features to the dEMG signal features might further improve the performance of such an algorithm. Pilot apnoea detection algorithms are already being published, based on other signals than dEMG.20 21 In any algorithm, signal artefacts must be managed in real-time, to prevent false detection or missing an event. The use of such an algorithm could improve the clinical outcome of these premature infants by enabling earlier intervention and adjusting clinical treatment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study demonstrates dEMG is a reliable technique for detecting changes in breathing pattern, that is, diaphragm activity, prior to an IH event, possibly enabling early intervention. A significant decrease and increase in dEMG activity were measured in central and obstructive IH events, respectively. Future research should focus on developing an automatic detection of these events using dEMG, and further investigate the origin of mixed events to enhance the classification and treatment of IH events.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank all parents for their consent to participate their child in the study.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Data availability free text: Data are available on reasonable request. Data are available on reasonable request to the corresponding author.
Patient consent for publication: Consent obtained from parent(s)/guardian(s).

Ethics approval: This study did not impose any additional procedures or rules on the patient, so the ethics committee provided a waiver for informed consent from the parents. However, informed consent was obtained from parents for anonymous data storage and usage to conduct the study (approval for this procedure was registered at the ethics committee as W20_232).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
